hints_html: Watch out for the multiple use of the chain rule.
hints_latex: Watch out for the multiple use of the chain rule.
hints_raw: Watch out for the multiple use of the chain rule.
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
Here we have several compositions going on. So a first step, would be to compute the derivative of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(x^2+2x)\end{aligned}\]

We do this using the chain rule:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle ( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\end{aligned}\]

Here we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = x^2+2x\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = 2x+2\end{aligned}\]

And so:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle ( \ln(x^2+2x) )' = \frac{1}{x^2+2x} (2x+2) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{aligned}\]

And so now, we can use the chain rule again to compute the derivative of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(\ln(x^2+2x))\end{aligned}\]

Using:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle ( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\end{aligned}\]

Where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = \ln(x^2+2x)\end{aligned}\]

and we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{aligned}\]

And so we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h'(x) = \frac{1}{\ln(x^2+2x)} \cdot \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{aligned}\]

:<math>\displaystyle
\ln(x^2+2x)
</math>

We do this using the chain rule:
:<math>\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)
</math>

Here we have that
:<math>\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = x^2+2x
</math>
and
:<math>\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = 2x+2
</math>

And so:
:<math>\displaystyle
( \ln(x^2+2x) )' = \frac{1}{x^2+2x} (2x+2) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}
</math>

And so now, we can use the chain rule again to compute the derivative of
:<math>\displaystyle
\ln(\ln(x^2+2x))
</math>

Using:
:<math>\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)
</math>

Where
:<math>\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = \ln(x^2+2x)
</math>
and we have
:<math>\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}
</math>

And so we obtain
:<math>\displaystyle
h'(x) = \frac{1}{\ln(x^2+2x)} \cdot \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}
</math>
